content: The Act is titled the "Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 1999" and it addresses the issue of soft money in political parties by amending the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The Act, known as the "Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 1999," amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to address the issue of soft money in political parties. National committees of political parties are prohibited from soliciting, receiving, or directing funds that are not subject to the limitations and reporting requirements of the Act. This restriction also applies to entities established or controlled by national committees and their officers or agents. The Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 1999 prohibits State, district, and local committees of political parties from using funds not subject to the Act's limitations for Federal election activities. This includes entities established or controlled by these committees and their officers or agents. The period for election-related activities includes voter identification, get-out-the-vote efforts, and generic campaign activities for Federal candidates. It also covers communications mentioning a clearly identified candidate for Federal office. The term 'Federal election activity' includes activities aimed at influencing a Federal election, excluding certain activities conducted solely for State or local candidates. The curr_chunk discusses allowable contributions for State or local offices, including costs for political conventions, campaign materials, and party committee expenses. It excludes compensation for individuals spending more than 20% of their time on Federal election activities. The curr_chunk explains the definition of generic campaign activity and fundraising costs for political party committees at various levels. The curr_chunk discusses the limitations and reporting requirements for fundraising activities by political party committees. The curr_chunk outlines restrictions on fundraising activities for candidates and entities related to federal officeholders under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The curr_chunk specifies limitations on fundraising activities for candidates and entities not related to federal officeholders under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The curr_chunk states that candidates for State or local office can participate in fundraising events for political parties, as long as it is permitted under State law for activities other than Federal election activities. Increased contribution limits for state committees of political parties and aggregate contribution limit for individuals have been raised. The contribution limit for state committees of political parties is amended to include a new limit for political committees established by a state committee exceeding $10,000 in a calendar year. Additionally, the aggregate contribution limit for individuals is increased from $25,000 to $30,000. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The reporting requirements under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 have been amended to include political committees, specifying that national and congressional political committees must report all financial activities. Additionally, other political committees subject to section 323(b)(1) must report receipts and disbursements for specific activities. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 has been amended to include reporting requirements for political committees, detailing that they must itemize receipts and disbursements exceeding $200 from any person in a calendar year. Additionally, a building fund exception to the definition of contribution has been revised. Section 8 of the National Labor Relations Act is amended to include a provision stating that labor organizations must establish an objection procedure for nonunion members who make payments in lieu of dues. Nonunion members must be provided with reasonable personal notice and opportunity to object to paying for organization expenditures supporting political activities unrelated to collective bargaining. If an objection is filed, the labor organization must adhere to the established procedure. Nonunion members must be given notice and the chance to object to paying for organization expenses related to political activities not linked to collective bargaining. If an objection is made, the organization must follow the specified procedure, including reducing payments by an amount reflecting the ratio of political expenditures to total expenses and providing a clear explanation of the calculation. The term 'expenditures supporting political activities unrelated to collective bargaining' refers to spending on elections or influencing legislation not related to collective bargaining.
